title: PTD Today — Media

items.title: How AI Empowers Artists. Watch the full episode on our channel now.

ai.summary: Based on the available description, this film accompanies Season 5 of the Webby Award–winning podcast Where the Internet Lives and links AI-driven creativity to the unseen world of data centers. It centers on how AI empowers artists and highlights the data and infrastructure that support creative tools and workflows.
bullets: Accompanies Where the Internet Lives Season 5 (Webby-winning podcast).
Focuses on how AI empowers artists and creative practices.
Frames creativity in the context of data, AI, and the data centers that host them.
Released by Google; viewers are directed to watch the full episode on the channel.
Uses hashtags: #WhereTheInternetLives #AI #Data #Creativity.
takeaways: Anticipate growing demand for GPU-heavy AI compute, storage, and bandwidth as creative AI tools scale—plan capacity and scalable architectures accordingly.
Prioritize energy efficiency, demand-response capability, and renewable integration to manage variable AI workloads tied to creative production.
Account for latency and connectivity needs of collaborative creative tools when selecting sites and network architectures.
Build procurement and lifecycle strategies for accelerators and storage (consider critical-minerals supply risk, reuse, and recycling pathways).

items.title: Boosting AI Performance: Networking for AI Inference

ai.summary: Based on the available description, Victor Moreno from Google Cloud explains how AI-aware networking (via GKE Inference Gateway and Cloud Load Balancing) addresses AI inference’s unique traffic patterns by using specialized metrics and routing. The approach adds prefix/body-based routing, cache-aware load balancing, LoRA adapter awareness, and network-level service extensions for API/guardrail insertion to reduce latency, improve GPU utilization, and cut costs.
bullets: Traditional networking and round-robin LB miss GPU saturation signals; inference-specific metrics (e.g., KV cache utilization, queue depth) are used to identify least-loaded replicas.
Prefix caching and shadow cache copies let the gateway reuse prefill computations to reduce GPU work and minimize cold starts.
Body-based routing and model identification (including LoRA awareness) enable routing to the best replica for a given prompt shape.
Service Extensions let API management and AI guardrails run in the network path to sanitize prompts/responses before they reach models.
Products highlighted: GKE Inference Gateway, Cloud Load Balancing, Google Kubernetes Engine (GKE).
takeaways: AI-aware networking can increase effective GPU saturation and reduce the number of idle or underutilized GPUs—potentially lowering required compute capacity and associated power/cooling needs.
Cache-aware routing and fewer cold starts can smooth peak demand and improve latency, aiding capacity planning for data center power and thermal systems.
Inserting guardrails at the network edge prevents invalid requests from consuming GPU cycles, directly reducing wasted compute cost and energy.
Unified, network-level routing and APIs can speed deployment and operational efficiency, impacting staffing and OPEX for facilities and IT teams.

items.title: Where Winds Meet is #RTXOn with DLSS 4 with Multi Frame Generation

ai.summary: Based on the available description, this NVIDIA GeForce clip showcases the open-world martial arts RPG Where Winds Meet running with #RTXOn and DLSS 4 with Multi Frame Generation. The short promo emphasizes NVIDIA graphics and performance tech, with video credit to @DigitalDreamsyt; no transcript was provided.
bullets: Features Where Winds Meet, an open-world martial arts RPG
Highlights DLSS 4 with Multi Frame Generation (MFG) and #RTXOn
Positions visual and performance enhancements as the focus
Video credited to @DigitalDreamsyt
No transcript available in the provided content
takeaways: Advanced GPU features shown (RTX, DLSS 4 with MFG) imply greater use of GPU-accelerated workloads—plan for potential increases in rack power and cooling capacity.
DLSS frame generation/upscaling can improve rendering efficiency per frame, which may reduce average compute per rendered frame and affect capacity planning for graphics-heavy services.
Ray tracing (indicated by #RTXOn) typically raises sustained GPU utilization—expect higher power draw and thermal loads for deployments focused on real-time rendering or visualization.
Deploying cutting-edge GPUs influences procurement timing and infrastructure upgrades; consider power delivery, cooling, and integration with on-site renewables or storage for resilient operation.

items.title: The backbone of your steam plant’s reliability | GE Vernova

ai.summary: Based on the available description, this GE Vernova video emphasizes the importance of anticipating the remaining life of an aging steam turbine rotor and deciding the right next steps to preserve plant reliability. It frames rotor end‑of‑life assessment as a core element of steam plant uptime and points viewers to GE Vernova resources for further guidance.
bullets: Aging steam turbine rotors are described as the backbone of steam plant reliability.
The video focuses on anticipating rotor remaining life and determining next steps.
Viewers are directed to GE Vernova resources for more information on rotor EOL.
GE Vernova positions itself as a partner in electrification and decarbonization.
No transcript was available; summary is based solely on the provided description.
takeaways: So what: Plan rotor end‑of‑life assessments proactively to reduce unexpected outages and protect grid/data center power continuity.
So what: Integrate rotor life forecasting into maintenance schedules and capital planning to optimize downtime and replacement timing.
So what: Factor procurement lead times and supply‑chain risks (including critical minerals and major components) into replacement or refurbishment decisions.
So what: Evaluate OEM engagement (e.g., GE Vernova) for lifecycle services and potential upgrades that align reliability with decarbonization goals.

items.title: Rynek dóbr luksusowych w obliczu transformacji | Andrzej Marczak, Tomasz Wiśniewski

ai.summary: Based on the available description, KPMG Poland’s podcast episode discusses how the luxury goods market is shifting toward experiences, personalization and “affordable luxury,” with growing emphasis on ESG and responsible sourcing. The conversation contrasts global softness with continued growth in Poland, touches on luxury in hospitality and the art market, and looks ahead to AI, craftsmanship and human-centered service.
bullets: Market trends: ‘luxury fatigue’, focus on experiences and personalization; Gen Z prefers experiences over ownership.
Customer concentration: top 2% of buyers represent ~40% of the market.
ESG/Responsible luxury: sustainability, eco-leathers and certification gaining importance.
Poland-specific: market still growing but fragmented; rising luxury tourism, hotels and spas (e.g., Baltic coast).
Future drivers: AI-enabled personalization, continued role for craftsmanship and brand storytelling (hotels, film).
takeaways: Hospitality and luxury tourism growth (hotels, spas) can create localized increases in power demand — consider capacity planning and grid reinforcement for tourist nodes.
AI-driven personalization and digital services highlighted as a future trend may raise data-center compute needs; factor this into forecasting for capacity, cooling and resilience.
ESG emphasis from luxury brands suggests rising demand for renewable energy, on-site generation and storage solutions as part of brand certification and sustainability claims.

Supply-chain focus on ‘responsible’ materials could increase attention to traceability and sourcing of critical minerals; infrastructure stakeholders should prepare for customer requests around provenance and sustainability.

items.title: PJM: Reliable Electricity is Our Priority

ai.summary: Based on the available description, PJM Interconnection emphasizes that reliability has been its primary mission since 1927. The video provides an overview of how PJM works to make sure electricity is available when customers need it.
bullets: PJM has prioritized reliability since 1927.
The content focuses on how PJM operates to ensure electricity is available on demand.
Intended as an explanatory/overview piece about PJM’s role in keeping the lights on.
Relevant to organizations that depend on continuous power supply.
takeaways: Treat PJM as the central regional authority on electric-system reliability when planning operations or expansions.
Integrate PJM reliability guidance and alerts into your outage, contingency and maintenance planning.
For data centers and critical facilities, ensure backup power and coordination plans align with PJM operations and communications.
Monitor PJM resources and communications to stay informed about regional reliability conditions that could affect supply.

ai.summary: Based on the available description, the video frames grid modernization as the need to balance reliability, flexibility, and efficiency while expanding capacity to support the energy transition. Hitachi Energy positions digital-first power grid technologies as a way to improve stability, reduce downtime, and optimize performance at every level.
bullets: Grid modernization must balance reliability, flexibility, and efficiency during capacity expansion for the energy transition.
Hitachi Energy emphasizes digital-first solutions for power grids.
Digitalization is presented as improving grid stability.
Digital tech is said to reduce downtime and optimize performance across system levels.
Positioning focuses on technology and operational benefits rather than specific products or materials.
takeaways: Prioritize digital grid solutions to improve stability and reduce downtime for substations and distribution networks.
When planning capacity increases for renewables and storage, explicitly weigh reliability, flexibility, and efficiency goals.
Data center operators and other critical-load owners should engage with grid modernization efforts to secure optimized performance and uptime.
The description focuses on digital/grid tech and does not address critical minerals or supply-chain impacts—assess material/resource implications separately.

ai.summary: Based on the available description, Hitachi Energy frames industrial resilience around energy efficiency, process optimization, and digital integration. The company emphasizes working with customers and partners to build smarter systems that boost productivity, reliability, and sustainability across operations.
bullets: Resilience built on energy efficiency, process optimization, and digital integration
Collaborative approach with customers and partners to deploy solutions
Focus on smarter systems that improve productivity and operational reliability
Sustainability is positioned alongside productivity and reliability goals
Call to action: learn more via the supplied link
takeaways: Prioritize digital integration and process optimization to improve grid and data center reliability and reduce operating costs
Evaluate vendor partnerships that combine efficiency, digital tools, and operational know-how to accelerate decarbonization and resilience
Smart-system investments can simultaneously raise productivity and sustainability metrics for renewables and storage projects

Description is high-level—seek technical details from Hitachi Energy on specific solutions, interoperability with substations/data-center power systems, and implications for critical-minerals supply chains
